conclusion: To determine the time when the light emerges from the arc surface ABC, we need to analyze the motion of the laser beam and the geometry of the semi-cylindrical transparent brick.
The radius of the semi-cylinder is r. The laser beam moves with a constant velocity v from point A to point C.
Light will emerge from the arc surface when the angle of incidence is such that the light refracts outwards.
The critical angle θ_c can be found using Snell's law: sin θ_c = 1/n.
The light will emerge from the arc surface when the angle of incidence at the point of incidence D along the arc is equal to or greater than the critical angle θ_c.
The distance AD where the light starts to emerge can be found using trigonometry: AD = r sin θ_c.

premise: The laser beam moves from point A to point D at a speed v.
conclusion: The time t to move from A to D is given by: t = AD/v = r sin θ_c/v.
The light will emerge from the arc surface ABC at the time: t = r/nv.
